articles.headline: Money-Market Pioneer and Son Cleared of Fraud
articles.snippet: The jury’s decision for Bruce Bent is the latest blow to S.E.C. efforts to hold individuals responsible for the risk-taking that led to the 2008 financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The jury’s decision for Bruce Bent is the latest blow to S.E.C. efforts to hold individuals responsible for the risk-taking that led to the 2008 financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators failed on Monday to win a clear victory over the father-and-son team whose mutual fund collapsed in one of the central blowups of the 2008 financial crisis. It was the latest setback in efforts by regulators to go after individuals responsible for risk-taking that nearly brought down the American economy.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Afghan Warlord’s Call to Arms Rattles Officials
articles.snippet: Ismail Khan, a former mujahedeen commander, is calling on his followers to reorganize and defend the country as Western militaries withdraw.
articles.abstract: Ismail Khan, a former mujahedeen commander, is calling on his followers to reorganize and defend the country as Western militaries withdraw.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERAT, Afghanistan — One of the most powerful mujahedeen commanders in Afghanistan, Ismail Khan, is calling on his followers to reorganize and defend the country against the Taliban as Western militaries withdraw, in a public demonstration of faltering confidence in the national government and the Western-built Afghan National Army.

articles.headline: Push Expands for Legalizing Same-Sex Marriage
articles.snippet: Buoyed by victories in four states, advocates of same-sex-marriage rights plan to press their cause in Delaware, Hawaii, Illinois, Rhode Island, Minnesota, New Jersey and Oregon.
articles.abstract: Buoyed by victories in four states, advocates of same-sex-marriage rights plan to press their cause in Delaware, Hawaii, Illinois, Rhode Island, Minnesota, New Jersey and Oregon.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me. — Elated by their first ballot victories, in four states, advocates of same-sex marriage rights plan to push legislatures in half a dozen more states toward legalization as they also press their cause in federal courts. They are also preparing for what they hope will be another milestone: the electoral reversal of a constitutional amendment defining marriage as solely between a man and a woman, in Oregon in 2014.

articles.headline: Facebook’s False Faces Undermine Its Credibility
articles.snippet: Fake accounts and fraudulent “likes” are an especially acute problem for Facebook as it has sought to distinguish itself as a place for real identity on the Web.
articles.abstract: Fake accounts and fraudulent “likes” are an especially acute problem for Facebook as it has sought to distinguish itself as a place for real identity on the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Facebook page for Gaston Memorial Hospital, in Gastonia, N.C., offers a chicken salad recipe to encourage healthy eating, tips on avoiding injuries at Zumba class, and pictures of staff members dressed up at Halloween. Typical stuff for a hospital in a small town.

articles.headline: The Leader of Windows Exits Microsoft
articles.snippet: Steven Sinofsky, the leader of Microsoft’s Windows business, is leaving the company, just weeks after the company released the biggest overhaul in decades of its flagship product.
articles.abstract: Steven Sinofsky, the leader of Microsoft’s Windows business, is leaving the company, just weeks after the company released the biggest overhaul in decades of its flagship product.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft has unexpectedly parted ways with Steven Sinofsky, the leader of one of its most lucrative businesses and an executive often mentioned as a possible successor to the current chief executive.

articles.headline: Trial to Open in $68 Million Insider Trading Case
articles.snippet: Prosecutors say Anthony Chiasson and Todd Newman were part of a conspiracy that made about $68 million illegally trading the shares of Dell and Nvidia.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors say Anthony Chiasson and Todd Newman were part of a conspiracy that made about $68 million illegally trading the shares of Dell and Nvidia.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the sharp-elbowed world of Wall Street, Anthony Chiasson and Todd Newman stood out as two of the good guys.

articles.headline: Democrats Like a Romney Idea on Income Tax
articles.snippet: With both parties positioning for negotiations on tax cuts and spending reductions, Democrats are latching on to an idea to raise taxes on the rich through a cap on deductions.
articles.abstract: With both parties positioning for negotiations on tax cuts and spending reductions, Democrats are latching on to an idea to raise taxes on the rich through a cap on deductions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With both parties positioning for difficult negotiations to avert a fiscal crisis as Congress returns for its lame-duck session, Democrats are latching on to an idea floated by Mitt Romney to raise taxes on the rich through a hard cap on income tax deductions.

articles.headline: A Dose of Realism for the Chief of J.C. Penney
articles.snippet: J.C. Penney reported last week that its sales had fallen 26.1 percent in the most recent quarter, but Ronald B. Johnson, its chief executive, promoted the success of the company’s store renovation plan.
articles.abstract: J.C. Penney reported last week that its sales had fallen 26.1 percent in the most recent quarter, but Ronald B. Johnson, its chief executive, promoted the success of the company’s store renovation plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: You should know you have a problem when sales at your stores fall 26.1 percent in one quarter.

articles.headline: Dynasty of Different Order Is Reshaping China
articles.snippet: Despite rising controversy over their prominent role, China’s princelings are emerging as a class that has an increasingly important say in ruling the country.
articles.abstract: Despite rising controversy over their prominent role, China’s princelings are emerging as a class that has an increasingly important say in ruling the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Maoists were trying to keep control of China in the 1970s, a powerful general from the south came to the aid of moderates, helping to arrest the radicals and throw them in jail. The bold actions of the general, Ye Jianying, paved the way for the country’s move to a more market-oriented economy, and created a political dynasty that still plays kingmaker, able to influence national policy and protect its sprawling business empire in southern China long after his death.

articles.headline: France Grants Its Recognition to Syria Rebels
articles.snippet: France on Tuesday became the first Western country to recognize the coalition, seeking to inject momentum into a broad effort to build a viable and effective opposition that would hasten the end of a stalemated civil war.
articles.abstract: France on Tuesday became the first Western country to recognize the coalition, seeking to inject momentum into a broad effort to build a viable and effective opposition that would hasten the end of a stalemated civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — France announced Tuesday that it was recognizing the newly formed Syrian rebel coalition and would consider arming the group, seeking to inject momentum into a broad Western and Arab effort to build a viable and effective opposition that would hasten the end of a stalemated civil war that has destabilized the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Virginia Tries to Circumvent Obama on Drilling
articles.snippet: The state is trying to restore through an act of Congress a lease sale for energy exploration that President Obama canceled in 2010 after the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.abstract: The state is trying to restore through an act of Congress a lease sale for energy exploration that President Obama canceled in 2010 after the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Doug Domenech looks out at the Atlantic Ocean, he sees oil and natural gas and jobs and revenue. Standing between him and those prizes are President Obama, the Navy and whales.
